empathy
item.description:
Seeking to understand/experience how another person is truly feeling, by analyzing/listening to their situation, so that we could have a better image of how and where from these feelings arose from, to be able to develop a hopefully accurate sense of how the other person is feeling, developing a connection through shared feelings.
empathy without actually feeling and instead faking the feelings is called reflection.
empathy is an essential social skill, and is especially powerful in validation.


empathy is different from sympathy by introduction of seeking genuine connection.
sympathy: "I'm sorry you're sad."
"This inconveniences me, and I don't like that."
empathy: "Wow, this is sad."
"I processed this, and I am also sad about it/think it is sad."
empathy is always important in any relationship, at any time/circumstance.
empathy is what allows us to receive feedback on the other person's feelings, and allows us to fairly accurately determine what is appropriate and what is not in the given situation.
When we observe/recognize how someone is feeling, we can then match their energy, and determine what is the appropriate way to behave/respond.
If the person is experiencing:
negative feelings: sad/exhausted/overwhelmed/hurting/grieving/etc...
Lower your energy and give them space. No pushing. The last thing they need is being given another reason to feel worse.
positive feelings: happy/excited/playful/giddy/etc...
Only if you have the energy to spare, and want to connect with this person: Raise your energy and join in their positivity! Be happy for them~


Get curious
think why this person may be feeling this way.
How would you feel if you've went through a similar experience?
What would have to happen to you to feel this way?
Look At Them
identify that this is an imperfect living being, a person with fears, desires, hopes, wants, and needs that is not unlike yourself, and that they are valid.
recognize that they may be going through pain, grief, or struggles otherwise that you may not be aware of, and how difficult they may be on the person, likely affecting their behavior, and if you were in a similar situation - you would likely respond and behave very similarly.
And that is not something to judge the person for, as you have your own struggles, and know how difficult they can be, and are - regardless of who understands them or not.
imagine Them As A Child
Imagine them as a small child, someone who has not yet had the time nor experience to develop a sense for what feelings are, what they mean, and how to process them.
This helps prevent judgment, and see the person more clearly.
Learn To identify Your Own emotions
Pay attention to how and what you feel yourself throughout the day, and why.
Perhaps leave a daily reminder.
Quit judging Your Own emotions
When identifying your own feelings and emotions - pay attention to if you are suppressing, avoiding, or accepting your own feelings and emotions.
dedicate your full attention to the person (read respect).

sympathy
item.description:
Looking at another person from the outside and experiencing personal feelings that stem from you, not from the other person.
sympathy occurs when you feel Bad/sad for someone who is experiencing a difficult situation that you either cannot relate to, or cannot spare the energy for.


"I'm so sorry you're going through this. It must be hard."
You are sorry that they are going through this, impartial to them.
You're not connecting by choice, by not thinking about how you would feel in that situation, whether because of Lack of care/interest, guessing "how it probably feels" instead. cold.
"I hope you get better soon. I hate to see you like this."
An expression of wanting to see the other get better soon, because it's difficult for us to see them in pain. An inconvenience to us.
"Seeing you sad makes me sad."
An observation, where the focus is you.
"You don't deserve to go through this."
- A personal opinion/observation.
Notice how all of these examples are expressing your own feelings, and speculating what it probably feel like, from the outside. The recipient or their feelings are never concerned with.


Unlike empathy: There is no connection, nor support. It's a personal expression of feelings and personal, impartial observations.
While the examples are negative feelings related; sympathy is not limited to them.
Example: unsolicitedly pushing a connectionless topic of personal interest, such as excitement (forcibly seeking reciprocation)/conflict (arguing/talking behind back)/narcissism (sharing stories/venting/trauma dumping) onto someone who shows no signs of reciprocation, even if they originally did (they probably used up their energy, since it is not their topic of interest: therefore they don't share that motivation/interest in it.), perhaps is even visibly (or invisibly) experiencing discomfort/irritation/concern/exhaustion, or even fear/danger/resentment from the relentlessness of the unsolicited, consentless pushing of their personal interests.

item.title: projection
item.description:
"Stop abusing me!" -The abuser, who mixed up what they are doing with what you are doing.
attribution/accusation of own feelings/behaviors to others.
projection is something that happens subconsciously, on an emotional level. The person using projection is not aware that they are, because if they knew that their emotions aren't based on them - they would stop making sense in their head, and disappear. For this reason: It is Incredibly difficult to get someone to become aware of their projection, as they will be defensive about being further "abused", or "manipulated".
projection is your mind recognizing how you feel, and refusing to accept it due to your relentless conviction of your beliefs, where your mind goes "Hmmm, am I out of touch? No, it's the kids that are wrong!", or "There is absolutely no way I could be this weak/petty/cruel/horrible to feel like this, I must be perceiving the other person's feelings instead of mine, yeah! It's them that are feeling this way! How dare they!!!", and projecting it onto the other, with full conviction that it's the other person feeling this way.
projection is a confession of your own feelings/actions, to someone else, as accusations/outbursts, that you cannot accept yourself.
This goes both ways:


If someone thinks they are loved by someone, but in reality: The person dislikes them, perhaps even hates them, and the person is actually projecting their own feelings onto this poor person being love bombed.


If someone is feeling angry and isn't aware of it themselves, they may project these feelings onto another person, and accuse them of being angry instead.


After calling someone names - a person may express "oh you're calling me names now?" to an observation, such as "Your behavior has been very disrespectful".


Defensiveness (I'm not defensive, you're defensive.)
Fear (I'm not psychology/mental processes/emotion/emotional processes/scared, you're psychology/mental processes/emotion/emotional processes/scared.)

validation
item.description:
validation helps us not only feeling heard, but also feeling seen, which may also come with feeling valued, both by the validating person, and by ourselves - through recognition of our validity via deduction, rather than words.
We seek validation because we have a want and need for recognition and acceptance, to be understood, and confirmation that our feelings are valid.
Unlike rephrasing, validation lets the other person know that you understand why they feel that way, and that you would likely feel that way too in their situation. Which without - would come off as unauthentic, and disconnected.
validation requires empathy. The better your empathy skills, the better your validation skills can become. Not sure what they're feeling? Ask! That's showing literal interest in their feelings.
validation is one of the most powerful social skills, and a basic human need that helps us form connections.
validation is essential for the health of a relationship.
validation can only be achieved without judgment. It is to allow a safe space for a person feeling safe enough to express their feelings and processing them, without labeling them as either either a "Good" feeling, or a "Bad" feeling, because feelings are not good or bad. They are feelings. Some are positive, some are negative and they all serve an important function.
validation is powerful with both positive feelings, and negative feelings, and they are both just as important to be validated!

negative feelings
helping them feel less crazy by acknowledging their struggles
, and providing them a safe space where they can express their feelings without worries and process them more effectively.
positive feelings
sharing and validating their joy, by letting them know that not only is it valid to have these feelings, but that you also support and encourage them, that you're happy for this person's happiness, further emphasizing the validation.
validation can be used even if you don't agree with the person. Usually to settle things before they get further out of hand (by validating their feelings, and calming their emotions) and hopefully provide an opportunity to share your perspective if applicable and help maintain the relationship.

effective validation can:

calmness:
psychology/mental processes/emotion/emotional capacities/feelings/fear
frustration
arguing
Promote:
excitement
reciprocation
connection
Assists:
acceptance of strong emotion, which allows for resolution via processing
Thanks to the newfound clarity: Finding the solution on their own, which is most likely the best solution for them


"I can't even imagine how that feels, that's really rough!!"
"I've been through something similar; it really hurts, doesn't it..?"
"I absolutely see why this is so difficult on you. It's a really tough situation. It feels really sad, doesn't it?"
"I don't know exactly how you feel as I've not been through this myself, and I want to be here for you regardless. It feels really rough, doesn't it."


Only offer a solution after ensurance that the person feels validated, and even then: empathize with the person and determine if it is appropriate in this situation to give advice; Would I want advice in this situation?
Chances are high that the person already knows the solution, and only seeks validation.
While seeking validation (Whether you're consciously aware that this is what you seek, or are seeking it subconsciously) and receiving a solution instead feels very frustrating, because the person is genuinely trying to help you, and is offering a genuine solution that may help with your situation - one you probably already thought of yourself and deduced why it wouldn't work, or deduced that it would work, yet that's not what feels relevant right now, because what you are truly seeking is validation of your feeling and emotions. What you hoped to receive from this topic is being sneakily shifted away, yet you have no one to accuse of doing anything wrong, because there is only genuinely positive intent.
If you want to be extra safe
Do not offer a solution at all. That will absolutely stick out in their memories as being genuinely listened to with 0 judgment and without your input as a distraction.
By not offering your solution: you never requested anything back.
We absolutely do enjoy giving our own input, it feels good to do so, knowing that the person learned something from you, making >you< feel better about yourself and taking away the focus from the person you are comforting.
The person experienced no distraction by you from their own feelings and emotions and instead only the validation you provided. It was all for them. This helps them feel important and valued. This will absolutely stick out in their memories and the next time they seek validation from someone else who is less skilled/experienced in validation, when the quality and results of their responsiveness will be put into contrast with yours. That is So bonding and special!
If you think the person has been adequately validated and you believe it'd be beneficial and appropriate to give them advice: validate them one more time and ask if they would like to hear your advice.
"Damn, that really is difficult. Would you like to hear my opinion?"
"Uhh, that's so unfair! Do you want to know what I think?"
"Yeah I've been through something like that too and it really is rough. Would you like to hear what I would do?"
Even if the person agrees to accept your advice - make sure if they actually want to hear it:
People may get socially pressured to accept advice/opinions that they do not want to hear, because it would be perceived as impolite of them. This makes us feel like we have no choice, and may cause negative feelings, such as resentment.
"Sure..."
"Okay..."
-sigh- "Fine..."
"Yeah, whatever..."
It is up to you to judge the situation and respond accordingly, and decide if you want to continue with sharing your advice or not. In the cases above: The answers were begrudging. You may want to hold back on your advice, unless you think it's really important to share it, like let's say your child really needs to hear this, even if through bitterness. Otherwise, you may instead back down and follow up with something like:
"I think that you're in a really tough spot and that really sucks. I sincerely hope you find a way to make it better, and I wish you luck with that."
And if instead the response was something more like:
"Yeah, I would really appreciate that!"
"That'd be great."
-sigh- "Yeah, I could use some advice."
You're good to go!
Of course do not give unsolicited advice if the answer is:
"I appreciate the offer and I will pass on it."
"No thank you. I just want to forget about it."
"Maybe another time, I'm too tired."
unsolicitation is rude and unwelcoming. It is disconnecting and invalidating.
asking someone if they would like to hear your advice/opinion shows respect, care, and value for their wants, preferences, and boundaries as a person and will most likely be appreciated, even if they reject your offer.
Avoid absolutes: expressing to someone that you know "Exactly" how they feel like can be invalidating and disconnecting, because no one truly has the exact same experience. We are all unique, and have come to exist the way we are over millions, if not billions, if not trillions of experiences.
absolutes can only be used effectively with people you have a strong bond with.
To ensure that your attempt is empathetic: keep your shared experience brief and end it with an invitation for the other person to continue.
Without this step, it may come off as sympathetic instead, as the focus/topic of the conversation has now been shifted to you.

To achieve effective validation:

Offer it before or instead of offering advice or assurance
identification of specific feelings/emotions
Offer justification for feeling that feeling/emotion



Offer micro validation
Super short and quick comments that are designed to validate, not only without shifting/interrupting from the topic, but actually emphasizing it.
"What!?"
"Yeah!"
"No fucking way!!"
"Right!?"
-exasperated sigh-/-Makes a disapproving face-/-Raises exposed palm to signify disbelief-
-feels supported and validated-

item.title: victim complex
item.description:
A manipulation tactic where a fake image of being a victim, with intent to lessen accountability and/or danger/consequences towards the (fake) victim.
victimization is extra dangerous, because conscious intent is not required.
Some people learn to play the (fake) victim role instead of dealing with their responsibilities in a healthy manner, and over time truly believe that they are a real victim.
victimization of self may be used as either means of protection (mental or physical) or acquiring benefits, such as better treatment, perception, or better chances at winning an argument.
The (fake) victim first assigns a (Fake) persecutor. The recipient of their accusations. The person being manipulated.
It works because people don't want to hurt others, and when they are assigned the persecutor role, it might make them feel guilty, insensitive, cruel, or even attacking an "innocent" (even if fake) (fake) victim, which will make them question themselves if perhaps they truly are hurting an innocent person, and they're the bad person (aka successful manipulation by the (fake) victim, that gives them an advantage).
The (fake) victim may also seek a (fake) rescuer (enabler, someone to vouch for the credibility of their (fake) victim claims), who's purpose is to enable the (fake) victim by validating their immoral views, and vouching the (fake) victim's victimhood to others, giving them extra credibility.
This makes the situation extra tricky, because it can still be effective, even if the person being manipulated is aware of this tactic, because even if they are aware of it, a different person that is not aware of the manipulation may fall for it instead, perceiving them as guilty, insensitive, cruel, or even attacking an "innocent" (fake) victim. This allows for non-verbal blackmail between the (Fake) persecutor, and the (fake) victim, that other people are Far less likely to catch up onto.

Example scene from a movie I forgot:
A woman comes up to a car with a baby in it, silently breaks in, and kidnaps the baby.
The father who is in charge of the baby, who was preoccupied for only half a minute on a phone call - thankfully notices the situation, and attempts to retrieve the baby.
The woman, however - plays (fake) victim, and screams that some man is trying to steal her baby.
The father - baffled - accuses her of lying.
A crowd gathers - the (fake) rescuers, and they stop the helpless father, as he watches his child be kidnapped.
The father, in a desperate final attempt to do save his child - remembers that he has photos of his child in his wallet, which he proceeds to take out.
Unfortunately, the photos only include the baby, and not the father.
The crowd proclaims him as a sick pervert, that he apparently took that extra step to gather pictures of this poor stranger victim's baby, and gets beat up almost to death.
It's even more effective if the person being manipulated is not aware of the initial tactic, as they will now be tempted to question their own deduction of the (fake) victim being a (fake) victim, and start questioning themselves - doing the (fake) victim's work for them - gaslighting themselves into believing that maybe this actually is a true victim, and that they have been doing a terrible mistake.
It can make the manipulated person feel uncomfortable in pursuing their original accusations/demands, whether they were reasonable, or not.
victimization manipulates people into giving them an advantage, by being given more compassion, leniency, and generosity, sometimes even resulting in an apology and/or compensation for their troubles, from the person that is being manipulated, and is in the right, unlike the (fake) victim.
It can also have the opposite than intended effect of insulting/infuriation/resentment towards the (fake) victim trying to play a true victim, if the other person has the mental fortitude, or experience in this tactic to see through the manipulative facade, worsening the case of the (fake) victim.

constructive criticism
item.description:
honest criticism, deliberately designed as constructive feedback.

constructive criticism has positive intent of providing honest, constructive feedback, with only the intent separating it from a deliberate insult.
constructive criticism is a skill.
A poor attempt at constructively criticizing due to lack of skill or otherwise will result in perception as an insult.
constructive criticism requires wisdom
Regardless of your skill in constructive criticism: using it appropriately is essential.
Whether due to poor history with the person, or lack of of receptiveness: your attempt at constructive criticism may fail.


avoid labeling and stating.
emphasize that this is your opinion rather than a fact.
imagine you drew a picture
insultingly criticizing
"That tree sucks."
"The sky is unrealistic."
"The face is all messed up."
Notice how insults are statements, suggesting that they are final by use of a label, invalidating opinions/interpretations of others.
constructively criticizing
"I think that tree looks off."
"In my opinion, the sky's hue doesn't match the rest of the scenery."
"It seems to me that there may be something off with the face."
Notice how criticisms are personal, suggesting that they are not final and that they are personal opinions, validating opinions/interpretations of others.

deflection
item.description:
deflection is a manipulation tactic designed to gain an advantage.
deflection is when a person avoids taking responsibility/receiving accountability by sneakily changing the topic towards a psychology/mental processes/emotion/emotional processes/struggle/Difficulty they have faced, which is only vaguely resembling of the current discussion, in an attempt to shift the topic focus to their own struggles/Difficulties, whether true or false, with intent of gaining sympathy/empathy points to lessen their responsibility, and reduction of chance to receive accountability.

Own Struggle
"i been trough shit earlier this year by the (some) community when I did this (horrible thing)"
"People (Instead of me, deflection.) made me face consequences when I did something wrong and hurt me. Don't be like them, don't attack me."
"Go blame someone else (Instead of me, deflection.)"
"you have problems with this video? then go to the video and tell in comments or stuff."
"If you want to blame/judge someone - this other person/people thinks/behaves this way too - go blame/judge them! (Instead of me, deflection.)"
"Actually it's okay to do it, because I've seen others do it. Go check the comments and you'll see how many people find it okay"
"Others (Instead of me, deflection.) do it - it's okay to do it."

item.title: disrespect
Analyse and Rewrite
item.description:
Emotional blackmail is when someone uses your emotions against you to manipulate your actions or decisions, often by creating guilt, fear, or a sense of obligation. The person doing the blackmail might make you feel like youre responsible for their happiness or well-being, pressuring you to do things you wouldn't normally want to do.

Imagine you have a friend who wants you to help them with something you don't have time for. You politely say no, but they respond with:
"I thought we were close, but I guess I was wrong. I just feel like nobody cares about me, and Im always left to struggle alone."
By saying this, they're trying to make you feel guilty, like you're somehow responsible for their sadness or loneliness. Even though you had a valid reason to decline, theyve framed it to imply that if you dont help, it means you dont care about them.
This tactic pressures you to give in because theyve used guilt and emotional manipulation instead of respecting your boundaries. The goal is to make you feel like you have to help them, even though it's not fair or reasonable to expect that.

A manipulation tactic where your emotions are used against you.
It is a commonly used in victim complex.
It involves assignment of artificial responsibility to someone for the manipulator's happiness/wellbeing, pressuring you to do something you normally wouldn't do by creation of false sense of guilt, fear, and responsibility for their happiness, or lack of.


Being accused of refusal to "understand their feelings", in an attempt to cause you emotions that would be manipulatively beneficial to them.
Usually followed by a condition and accusation that assigns blame, causing guilt and sense of obligation for you to correct the situation that is not yours alone to correct, by doing something you normally wouldn't do for them, because you are being manipulated.
"you need to understand my feelings before I can trust you."
In this example: emotional blackmail was used by:
accusation of refusal of trying to understand their feelings.
assignment of a condition for them to treat you better, causing a sense of responsibility.
accusation of being untrustworthy, making you feel shame and obligation to act more lenient towards them, which deflects their own responsibility to you, and reduces their accountability from your side.
May reflect their responsibility upon you via a baseless accusation.
"this goes both sides and you keep forgetting that"
emotional blackmail creates an illusion of fairness, but in reality: it's a power play designed to keep the control in their hands, and out of yours, in hopes of making you feel helplessness and powerlessness.


You are responsible only for your own happiness, and no one else's.
With a few exceptions such as your children, who you absolutely do have have responsibility over the happiness of).

reflection is fake validation, energy matching, and bonding used as a manipulation tactic.

item.title: respect Tips
item.description:
One of the most sincere forms of respect is truly hearing what the other person has to say (empathy).
Receiving respect makes us feel recognized, important (A priority) and feeling valued by the person showing the respect.



Whatever you may be focused on in the moment - prioritize your attention to the person (provided you want to give the person your respect).
Do not fool yourself that you can successfully fool the other person into believing that you are giving your full attention while you are not.
We as social creatures: pick up on social things automatically. It's in our nature.
If something feels off - we will have a sense for it, regardless if consciously, or subconsciously.
As an example:
Have you ever had a conversation with someone who accepted your request to have one, yet it feels like something else is on their mind? Like they aren't being present in the conversation?
Like your conversation is one-sided, or is simply not the primary focus, not the primary concern, like there is something more important to the person in the moment?
They may be able to repeat, perhaps even rephrase everything you said successfully, yet it still feels off? Like there is a disconnect between you two?
You're not crazy. And it wasn't rude or demanding or judgmental of you to observe this.
You simply paid attention to your social senses, that are telling you something feels off. Good Job!
This person attempted to fool your social senses, whether consciously or unconsciously. They may not have done it out of malice specifically. However, it was still inconsiderate and rude of them.
It really doesn't feel good, to know that the other person is prioritizing you and the activity you were both meant to be sharing below whatever is on their mind instead, does it?
significantly worse than if the person never accepted the conversation in the first place, because then: at least your emotional energy and time would not have been wasted.
Don't be like them.
Fully pause what you're doing.
Help them feel heard, show them they're important to you.
Make them a priority over your now-past activity.
Pause your video.
Take out your earbuds.
Take off your headphones.
Take out your earplugs.
Note that for the 3 items above there may be a concern of damaging your hearing in a loud environment, or introduction of a source of irritation for your sensitive hearing, in which case you should absolutely prioritize your safety and comfort. put on your oxygen mask first.
Put away your book.
Put away your phone.
Put it out of sight.
phones are your gateway to the rest of the world. Studies have shown that having your phone out in sight, even if the screen is off is subconsciously worrying of being less important in the conversation. It is disconnecting.
Look at the person.
If you're uncomfortable with that for any reason - look away from your previous activity. From anything that would indicate your attention is elsewhere.
Clock
Window
Puzzle
Above and beyond extra special gestures, that are So overkill, that you simply Must recognize and appreciate, knowing they were done for you, even though they weren't strictly necessary.
Turn off the monitor/tv entirely.
Shut the laptop close, even if it's only showing a blank screen.
If you are currently too busy and truly cannot dedicate your full, undivided attention to the person, to a point where it would hurt you or otherwise significantly inconvenience you in some way - whether it's a deadline, stress, or current inability due to exhaustion or otherwise - then don't! Instead:
express this to the person. Let them know that while you cannot provide your full attention that they and their troubles are still important to you despite it.
"I'm sorry, this isn't a good time for me right now. This sounds important and I would like to give you my full attention and I am too exhausted to do that right now."
"Sorry, I am in the middle of a stressful deadline that's due in a few hours from now and I would be distracted by it if we were to talk about this right now and that would not sit right with me. Can we talk in an hour? I want to give you my full attention."
Being honest with the person shows that you trust them enough to be transparent with them (as opposed to an excuse) and maintains your boundaries which the person will likely recognize and decide on their own terms (instead of being told "My worries are more important than your worries, which would do nothing but hurt the relationship.) that your needs and boundaries have higher priority than their issues and choose to respect them.
Your confidence and emotional capacity to be able to protect your boundaries is admirable, and worthy of respect, perhaps even looking up to.
It is a Far more effective tactic than:
Making up excuses to "spare" their feelings (hurting them instead through lack of sincerity, showing them they cannot be trusted with the truth and instead given excuses.)
enduring the inconvenience and pushing through regardless.
potentially causing resentment towards the situation that you allowed to happen.
exhausting yourself even further and showing lack of attention to the person by being inattentive, showing a lack of interest - which is disrespectful instead.
All of the above hurting the relationship, instead of developing it.
Of course urgency is absolutely a factor. If the person comes in all panicked, in shock, or distressed otherwise - the appropriate priority must be established.

item.title: sarcasm
stonewalling
item.description:
An emotional blackmail power play manipulation tactic that ensures that the manipulator has the final word, which is most often another manipulation tactic intended to gaslight the target, as they are made unable to respond to the message/sentence by the manipulator. This is an attack from within the Victim's head that is intended to simultaneously rile up the victim, and render them powerless in the situation, with hopes that they also start feeling that way. It is a cruel manipulation tactic.
The victim will now likely feel anger/fear/guilt/responsibility that the attacker intended them to feel.
the victim's sense for justice will likely start looking for a target to act as an outlet to the injustice that they have been put through.
With the manipulator no longer being available for communication - it's more than likely that the closest person that would understand the injustice, and the psychology/mental processes/emotion/emotional processes/struggle that comes with bearing it is the victim themselves.
Depending on their mental fortitude and emotional maturity - the victim may start fighting the image of the attacker in their head now.
Afterall, who could blame them? injustice was thrown their way, and it is their obligation to defend their image, as no one else will! How dare this person accuse me of these unfair things? They're such a jerk!!!
The problem is that an image of anyone in your head is still you. Fighting an image of yourself in your head: is fighting yourself. This is exactly the intent of the attacker - for you to eat away at yourself, with their attack as the seed for all the terrible emotions.
stonewalling is a mental parasite:

If you choose to ignore it: Chances are likely that it will keep on festering inside you until you can no longer ignore it. Until it gets out of hand.
If you have the mental skills to combat this manipulation tactic safely and choose to do so: It will still require your mental and emotional energy.
stonewalling prevents closure, ending things completely on the attacker's terms.


"you need to understand how i feel or else there is no way i will understand how you feel, this goes both sides and you keep forgetting that goodbye.... miss (Name)..."
emotional blackmail, suggesting (and hoping you believe it yourself, too) that the stonewalling was caused solely by you - that you were so stubborn that you couldn't get over yourself (Promotes feeling guilt) and have left them with no choice but to block (stonewall) you, which they express through reluctancy, again suggesting that they are stonewalling you with a heavy heart, like your relationship was so important to them.
The missing context here being that the person has been manipulating you this entire time, while you kept your composure, and behaved respectfully. Unlike them.

item.title: thinking
item.description:
thinking is essential before throwing yourself into new experiences, however, only so much thinking will get you so far.
thinking has a surprisingly quick falloff for bringing fruitful insight, before it becomes fruitless, and even harmful. Before it becomes overthinking.
This is why it is essential to think about a situation, but never overthink.

item.title: triangulation
item.description:
A more complex and severe form of victim complex, where the manipulator involves one or more third-party, often with heavy use of deliberate omission of relevant information via willful ignorance, downplaying their own responsibility in the matter via deflection, and deflecting the responsibility upon the target.
triangulation usually starts with involvement of closest people to the manipulator, who are most likely believe them, and play along as their (fake) rescuer - often emotionally blackmailing them into cooperation.

The purpose is to recruit allies to take their side, fueling their victim complex, enhancing their power play, and leaving you helpless and powerless in the situation, with others on the manipulator's side.
taking things public pressures the target, as the situation has been escalated without their consent, potentially against their preferences.
It also puts the target into a disadvantage due to the intentional omission of truth and relevant context.
It also pressures the target into feeling cornered, by threat of feeling outnumbered.
The manipulator also assigns the victim as the target for the abuse that the manipulator is claiming to have been put through. This pressures the target into feeling like they need to defend themselves against the false accusations, that the third-parties are not aware are false, due to the omission of truth by the manipulator.

item.title: willful ignorance
item.description:
deliberate omission of information that would prove you incorrect, and hoping that anyone else involved doesn't catch onto it either, so that you could feel/Be perceived as correct.
willful ignorance is always harmful. It is a gaslighting technique.
It expresses "If I dont acknowledge it, its not real.", dismissing any legitimate concerns.

Sometimes it's mild, like a child that's adamant on being unable to learn something new - suddenly realizing that they learned something new.
The child could now willfully pretend that they in fact did not learn anything, that it's impossible, that the people who claimed that they could learn were wrong, and may even take fitful steps to "prove" that they did not - even if it's blatantly obvious for the older kids/adults that they are throwing a tantrum.
And sometimes it's incredibly harmful, when used as a manipulation tactic, to willfully ignore someone's efforts, such as an expression that would either resolve/solve the conversation/argument, or as little as prove that the willfully ignorant person is incorrect.
The willfully ignorant person would not acknowledge the parts that are problematic to their point, suggesting to the target that either the willfully ignorant person simply does not understand and may not deserve to be responsible for the entire blame due to their lack of understanding, or that they should put in even more effort into explaining now, becoming further exhausted, only for it to be wasted once again, and be further willfully ignored, and less likely to catch onto further attempts at manipulation, due to lack of energy.
willful ignorance also appears as a person that has been manipulating you and giving you a hard time - suddenly treating you especially friendly, perhaps even defending you, where you didn't even need defending - only in hopes of being perceived as your ally, completely ignoring all the drama that they have caused while manipulating you. This is a form of gaslighting, as you are tempted to question your perception of the situation, and it's especially difficult now because you are aware that if you bring up the abuse/manipulation caused by the manipulator - you will come off as looking for trouble/causing drama, so you are more likely to endure the gaslighting instead, perhaps even give into it and start questioning your perception "Maybe they're actually a nice person, and I am the one who is dramatic, and trying to cause trouble out of nowhere. That's so immature of me".

item.title: disconnection
item.description:
Is the vibe of not being on the same page. When you and the other person are doing the same activity/Are in the same conversation, but are seemingly perceiving two different experiences.


You are Super excited over the upcoming holiday with your best friend, you express how wonderful it's going to be, how much you cannot wait to see all the Beaches/Snow, and yet they don't seem to share your enthusiasm one bit.
"It's as if they don't even care..."
Your friend is Super interested in this stupid little car figurine, and you just cannot understand why. They push it into your face all excited and you just don't know what to do with that request, and cannot think of what to respond with, so you just stare at it and your friend...
"Uhhh, what the hell do they expect me to say..? It's just a stupid toy..?"
When you're feeling awful about something and seek validation from your family member, and they offer you a solution instead...
"It's like they don't even care for about my feelings... I feel even worse now, I feel misunderstood, I feel alone..."
When the person you're with is Incredibly worried about something you don't see the significance of, like if you let's say got a small cut that bled a little, or slipped on the ground and didn't really hurt yourself, or got sick from getting too cold, yet the other person is freaking out. You explain the situation and it's severity (or rather: lack of), and the other person seemingly only worries more. It feels disconnecting.
Surely the victim - which is you - knows the severity of the damage/seriousness better than the other person - and you have confirmed that there is nothing to worry about.
Depending on the person - you may even really appreciate their care and worry, yet the fact is that their worry is now bringing you extra stress and worry, which in case of sickness - may actually escalate the sickness, potentially worsening the severity of it, and prolonging it.
"I already explained my symptoms in full without sugarcoating anything and yet they're still worried, and I can tell there is nothing I can do... I wish we could be on the same page again, because I really appreciate their love, care, and support, to help me feel better by being here for me and being strong for me, because I surely am not strong myself right now. Instead of causing me to worry and stress about their worries and stressing about me... I don't want them to feel bad over me, it makes me feel guilty and encourages me to focus the little spare energy I have remaining that is Much better spent fighting off my sickness and helping me recover, instead of worrying about how difficult I am making it on them, causing me to expend some of my currently extra precious energy to making sure they have it easy as possible..."

item.description:
rosy retrospection of fading/faded/unknown/assumed, blurry information being filled in favourably by our imagination in our perception of the image/memory, personalizing our interpretation of the information:
blurry or tiny picture you can just barely recognize, or almost make sense of
Tiny/old song thumbnails that you would Really like to see better, because you give them more value with your imagination, because you cannot see the information clearly.

Chopped/muffled vocals where they barely, or almost make words/sentences you can recognize
My favorite type of vocals in my music, and my favorite type of music in general thanks to ambiguous allure!
Most of the songs in my feeling of magic category use this technique!
alex s. - my little pony intro remix
"My little pon-n-y", kind of!
"P-p-pony, p-p-pony, p-p-pony p-p-p-p-p-p-p-p-!",

daniel ingram - my little pony Intro (174udsi remix)

Brohoof Studios - Dance Magic (Cosine Pitchshifterz Remix)
"falling across the floors! Falling across the floor!"
"falling across the floor! deep down in ins- deep down!"
"falling across the floors! Falling- fa- fa- falling across the floor! d-dj give it more!"
"deep down inside my soul! deep down inside my s-! deep deep inside my soul!"
"d-d-deep down inside my side my, side my s-! deep down inside my soul!"
"deep down inside my s- deep deep down inside my soul! d-dj give it more!"
igna - Flutter
"He taught me!",
"He did everything, we did everything, to-gether!",
"He taught me - he taught - to fly a kite, kite!",
All of which for "some odd reason" (ambiguous allure) capture our attention and cause us feelings (such as nostalgia, longing, sadness, wanting, desires) and invokes our emotions (causing goose bumps, tears/crying, seeking comfort), and are overall perceived as mysterious, special, and significant/important. They feel magical!
Because of ambiguous allure, there are songs that you've never heard, that were just released that sound and feel nostalgic!
ambiguous allure causes curiosity, interest, and seeking of whatever it may be that caused it.
ambiguous allure is what makes us so interested and curious about things we do not understand. We want to learn, to explore, to understand things we haven't yet. What magical experiences await us? We do not know and we want to find out! To seek the feeling of magic!
ambiguous allure is what makes growing up so magical, endlessly full of curiosity, desire to learn all there is to learn, to explore everything! It's all new to us! It is a strong motivation of children to understand the world they live in, to one day become capable adults by seeking knowledge and tools for our futures!
ambiguous allure is also what makes being grown up feel so lacking in comparison to growing up. After we have established what is and what is not.
The mystery about the entire world is gone: reality sets in. Our once-mysteries are now established facts/roughly estimated concepts, educated guesses.
We roughly know what to expect from the next week, month, year, etc... This is mundane, and it makes us feel stale. Like nothing will change.
If we do nothing about it, we reach equilibrium, and if we stay in equilibrium for too long, we may enter limbo. We absolutely do not want to enter limbo! Not only is it life-draining, it is Incredibly more difficult to escape with every day in it! You have to re-learn how to live and what living means. You need to rehabilitate, without the hope, warmth, or motivation that you are trying to re-access.
In this terrible fate: even our most wonderful, cherished dreams become faded memories of the past, something we can no longer experience or feel, eventually even remember. A horrible fate.
This is why it is extremely important to find something to replace the benefits ambiguous allure provides, before lack of them sneakily creep up on us, and doing something about it becomes too difficult on our own!
We need
support
friends and family, kin
To feel
seen
valued
loved
safe
motivated
motivation
hobbies
hopes
dreams
dedication
ambiguous allure is why nostalgia is so powerful.
memories of positive past events fade more and more, creating more and more gaps to be filled in and be reinterpreted more and more favorably as time goes on. We remember feelings most effectively.
ambiguous allure is part of why we have interest in and awe of ancient history - something that is completely irrelevant to our current age and lives.
The more mystery, the stronger the effect!
ancient egypt Pyramids! How did they build them!? Was it aliens? gods? unlikely! In fact, almost guaranteeably not! We know this, yet the fact that it is not known as an inarguable fact entices us, despite the chance being 0.00000000001% or however low it may be. If anything, that only makes it more effective and interesting, the "What If" aspect of it.
ambiguous allure is the true culprit of the blame infatuation gets assigned.
The unknown, the mystery of just how wonderful this person simply Must be, with how perfect and angelic they have been! The other person becomes an object of worship.
The more desperately we want/need something, the more we look out for potential signs of that thing.
If someone feels lonely, they will seek relief from their loneliness, pain, and suffering.
When reciprocated: Great!!! Unless it unfortunately fades, which it might. Then again, it might not.
That fully depends on the quality of the relationship's base
weak relationship base
Based on nothing: A weak relationship base will soon collapse upon itself, as it tries to grow further and further without the strength or health to support, or even sustain itself, dooming it's potential future before it gets to blossom.
strong relationship base
Based on true values: A strong relationship base will allow for synergy, giving the relationship the strength and support it needs to achieve new heights and sustain them effortlessly, even with less effort than the previous, lower level of the relationship, as the growth of the relationship also grows the base of the relationship, making it bigger and stronger. blossoming and blooming into something wonderfully beautiful together~
A beautiful, healthy, and wonderful display of rose-tint~
When unreciprocated: More and more disconnect is created, as the person worshipped does not feel the same about the worshipper. equality is lost, replaced by disconnect. inability to feel as equals.

backhanded compliment
item.description:
An insult maliciously disguised as a compliment.


"That's pretty smart, for someone without an education/your age."
Attack on the person's education level, or age.
sincere alternative: "Wow, that's really smart! If I didn't know, I would've thought you: graduated from a university/you're older than that!"
Lack of education and being young are used to emphasize the impressiveness of their smartness!
"You're lucky to be loved by someone so good, despite all your quirks."
Attack on the person's quirks.
sincere alternative: "It's great that you found someone who loves you and your quirks, it really shows how sincere their love is towards you!"
Their quirks are instead portrayed as a positive trait, which compliments the sincerity and genuinity of the love! How kind!
"For a beginner, you did a good job."
shifting the focus of the person's accomplishment to the fact that they're a beginner, rudely diminishing the compliment part.
sincere alternative: "You did a good job, especially for a beginner!"
The focus of the sentence is now the good job, which comes first - and them being a beginner only emphasizes their accomplishment! How sweet!
backhanded compliments shift the focus from the insincere compliment into an insult, using the compliment to create plausible deniability for the insult, making it more elusive, to a point where the person being insulted may either be gaslighted into believing that they are just imagining the malice since it is "obviously a compliment" or simply not recognizing the insult in the first place and be sincerely grateful towards the person insulting them.
This makes backhanded compliments especially nasty, usually used as an abuse of power against those that are:
aware of the nastiness but cannot defend themselves due to a power imbalance
A boss backhandedly complimenting an employee and the employee having no realistic choice but to pretend that they are not aware of the disguised insult and respond positively to their boss. A disgusting abuse of power and power imbalance.
unaware of the nastiness, to the enjoyment of the person insulting, where they humiliate the person without them even knowing.
Older, smarter kid or adult backhandedly complimenting a younger, less aware kid or adult.

item.description:
This involves flipping the responsibility to "prove" onto you repeatedly, even after youve given proof. They make you feel like no amount of evidence will ever be enough to satisfy them because theyve already decided to reject anything you offer.

A manipulation tactic where the manipulator demands you to "prove" yourself, despite the fact that you have provided legitimate proof, and the manipulator has not.
The responsibility of providing legitimate proof is flipped onto the person (The manipulated) who has provided it, by the person (The manipulator) who has not.
burden reversal manipulatively challenges the target's image instead of the actual issue at hand, which is an example of deflection.
Similarly to willful ignorance, it is designed to gaslight you into exhaustion, being put into a position where you are now expected to defend your image, before you can even consider addressing the actual topic at hand again.
Even if you are aware of this manipulation tactic: you're still put at a disadvantage, as the manipulator now has increased confidence and conviction in them being correct, because you were "Unable to defend your image", therefore you have something to hide/are showing weakness.

item.title: constructive feedback
item.description:
Part of effective communication.
feedback structured in a constructive manner, directly addressing the quality being given feedback to and making it clear that this is both constructive and feedback - whether it is positive or negative, rather than an insult.

constructive feedback is a skill.
Both constructive criticism and constructive complimenting take a lot of skill and thought to be utilized effectively.
Upon failure:
constructive criticism is generally more insulting, rude, and volatile.
constructive complimenting is generally more confusing, awkward, and embarrassing.

control
item.description:
Having the ability to influence over a process, or outcome.


If you want to eat
You need control over your mind, especially if you are currently busy/distracted with something else.
You need control over your body to physically seek out this goal.
If you want to hold someone accountable and take responsibility:
You need control over the situation
You need to have the authority over this person, which is a type of status, which is a type of control.
If you want your higher-up to take responsibility while you are an employee, or even an intern, then you likely do not have the control in this matter without major consequences, most likely losing your employment, while your higher-up will face no accountability.
You need control over your thoughts to be able to express your idea/concerns to the person, or another person that would hold the authority to be able to hold this person accountable.
You need control over your emotions to be able to effectiveness express your thoughts.

distortion
item.description:
When memories/perception of new events are blurred due to lack of information, and the gaps are filled in by our imagination, and taken as real.

distortion comes in both negative and positive variants.
rosy retrospection is the positive alternative.
Our minds do this because they are optimized to take shortcuts in order to reduce energy requirements by interpolating the gaps.
Examples
imagine your roommate is going shopping and offers you if you want anything from the shop. You ask them to get some bananas for you. After a while, you go to the kitchen and see that they have indeed went shopping, bought several things they previously expressed needing to get for themselves, yet you see no bananas.
The facts:
Your roommate offered you to get something for you from the shop.
Your roommate knows you would like bananas from the shop.
evidently, your roommate went to the shop and bought some items.
The items were something your roommate was planning to get.
You cannot find the bananas anywhere.
The potential truths:
Your roommate forgot about their offer, and your response.
Depending on your relationship with your roommate, this may be the first conclusion your mind jumps to. Especially if your relationship is negative.
There were no bananas in the shop.
There were bananas, but they were Way overpriced.
There were bananas, but they looked Way too ripe to be worth getting.
The truth:
The truth and reality is unknown until asked your roommate tells you. You weren't there.

effective communication
item.description:
references
validate
Don't try to fix it!
Being constructive
constructive feedback
constructive criticism
constructive complimenting
connect
invite them to open up by providing them a safe space.
help them feel heard and feel valued by listening to their concerns, difficulties, and struggles, and validating the feelings and emotions caused by them.
observe their feelings and emotions
body language
Someone may convey shyness, timidness, confidence, etc... In their body language.
language
intonation
"I'm Really tired..."
"I absolutely Love that!"
tone of voice
Someone may convey anger, sadness, tiredness, etc... In their voice.
recognize the appropriate behavior in the current situation.
If someone is being reluctant - you may deduce that they are: embarrassed, worried about being judged or harmed or otherwise, or that they are experiencing some sort of discomfort through some other way.
This is important information that helps us decide what is the most appropriate way to proceed with this conversation, such as:
taking a break
giving some space
Advancing the topic
respecting boundaries
etc...
match their energy
It is disconnecting to have different energy levels in a conversation.
If you are excited and share something you are happy about - you are most likely doing so in hopes of receiving validation. This is a request for validation, whether it is done consciously, or unconsciously.
If the person you shared your excitement with matches the energy - you will feel connected, understood, and validated, like your excitement is justified and deserve to feel good about it.
"Wow, that does suck!"
"Uh, yeah, I get that, long conversations like that sure are tiring. Especially if the person is being so frustratingly stubborn..."
"That's so exciting!"
"Right!? Thank you!!"
If the person you shared your excitement with does not match your energy - you will feel disconnect - your emotional energy will drop and you will likely use further emotional energy to defend/justify/analyze your feeling good, which is already spoiling your feeling good, and you may even start to doubt yourself if it's okay to feel your excitement in the first place... Especially if the person had malice in their expression, not just being neutral.
Be honest
When someone asks for your opinion - it's obvious and feels infinitely worse to sugarcoat the truth, rather than sharing your honest opinion.
imagine playing a competitive game that means a lot to you, that you prepared for by practice for the past few weeks/months/years, and under-performing on the day of the event.
Let's say this was the rythm game Osu! and you failed miserably and lost the competition.
Now imagine you approach your best friend, and express "I just don't know what happened with me; I messed up so bad! I feel so embarrassed!.."
And now imagine if your best friend replied with:
"No you didn't mess up, you did great!"
You know that's not true. You lost because you messed up. It was a literal skill check, and you lost.
This expression is disconnecting because you're not on the same page with your best friend, and invalidating because you feel like you failed, and you feel embarrassed. Your request for validation has been declined with sugarcoating.
"Yeah, you did mess up. I don't know what happened with you today either. I saw you practicing myself and today was so unlike you. How could you not feel frustrated..?"
You already knew you messed up, and receiving confirmation of your observations and validation of your feelings is connecting.
